hypotheses.prediction: IF purified human VDAC1 is reconstituted in planar lipid bilayers and exposed to valproic acid (50–700 µM), THEN single-channel open probability (Po) will shift by ≥15% relative to vehicle, with an EC50 between 100–500 µM.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Reconstitute purified recombinant hVDAC1 (E. coli expression, refolded in LDAO) into DPhPC planar bilayers using the painting method. Record single-channel currents at ±30 mV under voltage-clamp before and after sequential VPA additions (10, 50, 100, 300, 700, 1000 µM) to the cis chamber. Analyze Po, conductance substates, and gating kinetics across ≥5 independent bilayers per condition. Timeline: 6–8 weeks.
hypotheses.expected_outcome: VPA at 100–700 µM shifts Po by >15%, likely toward open state (fatty acid analog behavior), with
hypotheses.null_outcome: No statistically significant change in Po, conductance, or gating kinetics at any VPA concentration up to 1 mM across ≥5 bilayers (p > 0.05, paired t-test).
controls: Vehicle (equivalent Na⁺ addition as sodium valproate)

hypotheses.prediction: IF primary mouse hepatocytes or HepaRG cells are exposed to hepatotoxic APAP concentrations (5–20 mM), THEN LC-MS/MS of immunoprecipitated VDAC1 will reveal NAPQI adducts (mass shift +149.05 Da) on Cys127 and/or Cys232 in ≥60% of biological replicates, with adduct abundance correlating with APAP dose (Spearman ρ > 0.7).
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Treat HepaRG cells (CYP2E1-competent) with APAP (1, 5, 10, 20 mM) for 2, 6, and 12 h. Isolate mitochondria by differential centrifugation, immunoprecipitate VDAC1 (anti-VDAC1 ab15895), digest with trypsin/chymotrypsin, and analyze by nanoLC-MS/MS (Orbitrap) with targeted PRM for Cys127/Cys232-containing peptides ± 149.05 Da modification. Parallel: BSO pre-treatment (GSH depletion) and NAC co-treatment arms. Timeline: 10–12 weeks.
hypotheses.expected_outcome: NAPQI adducts detected on Cys232 (most accessible) at ≥5 mM APAP by 6 h, increasing with
hypotheses.null_outcome: No NAPQI adducts detected on any VDAC1 cysteine at any dose/timepoint despite confirmed adducts on known targets (GAPDH, GST), indicating VDAC1 cysteines are not preferentially modified by NAPQI in situ.
controls: NAPQI direct addition to isolated mitochondria (cell-free positive control)

hypotheses.prediction: IF VDAC1 is reconstituted in bilayers pre-doped with atorvastatin or simvastatin at membrane concentrations equivalent to myopathic tissue exposure (1–10 µM bulk, yielding ~100–1000 µM membrane concentration given logP ~4), THEN VDAC1 conductance will decrease by ≥20% and voltage-dependent closure will shift by ≥5 mV (V₀ shift), compared to cholesterol-only membranes.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Reconstitute hVDAC1 in DPhPC/cholesterol (80:20) planar bilayers. Pre-incubate lipid mixtures with atorvastatin, simvastatin, or pravastatin (hydrophilic control) at 0.1, 1, 5, 10, 50 µM before bilayer formation. Record multichannel and single-channel I-V curves from -60 to +60 mV in 5 mV steps. Calculate G-V curves, V₀, and gating charge. Compare statin-doped vs. vehicle-doped membranes. Confirm membrane incorporation by fluorescence anisotropy (DPH). Timeline: 8–10 weeks.
hypotheses.expected_outcome: Atorvastatin and simvastatin (logP ~4–5) shift V₀ leftward by 5–15 mV and reduce maximal conductance by 20–40% at ≥5 µM bulk concentration, consistent with altered bilayer mechanics. Pravastatin (logP ~−0.8) shows no effect. Effect magnitude correlates with membrane statin content.
hypotheses.null_outcome: No significant difference in conductance, V₀, or gating parameters between statin-doped and
readouts: statin membrane concentration (LC-MS of bilayer lipid extract)

hypotheses.prediction: IF purified VDAC1 is exposed to metformin (0.01–10 mM) in reconstituted bilayers, THEN no change in conductance or gating will be observed (ΔPo < 5%, Δconductance < 10%); HOWEVER, in intact mitochondria, metformin (1–10 mM) will reduce VDAC-dependent metabolite flux (ATP/ADP exchange measured by luciferase) by ≥30%, an effect abolished by Δψm clamping with FCCP.
